description: From Middle English prat, from Old English præt, prætt (“trick, prank, craft, art, wile”), from Proto-West Germanic *prattu, from Proto-Germanic *prattuz (“boastful talk, deceit”), from Proto-Indo-European *brodno- (“to wander about”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian prat, Dutch pret (“fun, pleasure, gaity”), obsolete Dutch prat (“cunning, strategem, scheme, a prideful display, arrogance”), Low German prot, Norwegian prette (“trick”), Icelandic prettur (“a trick”). Related to pretty.

adjectives.description: prat (comparative more prat, superlative most prat)

entries.meaning: (now Scotland) A cunning or mischievous trick; a prank, a joke. [from 10th c.]

description: Unknown. Perhaps a specialised use of Etymology 1 (see above).

entries.meaning: (slang) A buttock, or the buttocks; a person's bottom. [from 16th c.]

examples: "She's a far better pieceThan the Viceroy's niece,Who has also more fur on her prat."
